Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2009 01:17PM desdemona222b wrote: My God, what an ordeal!  I had to have emergency surgery the day after my lumpectomy too, but I didn't go through all that.  I have also been in the hospital emergency room and they blew every single vein in my arm.  Guess why?  When you're in shock, you blood pressure drops, and your veins get very tiny.  After going through the human pin cushion deal, someone told me that all they need to do was give me a little oxygen and the veins would've been fine. I would definitely get in touch with the hospital director and tell him in no uncertain terms what you went through.  Hope there's another hospital in your area in case you ever have another emergency.  Wow - what a story!

It really helps to have someone around with a sense of humor, as well. My dear son kept me laughing while I waited for the final results of the pathology report, which is always nerve wracking. I went through what you ladies are going through in January 6 years ago this month and my life is completely back to normal!  I know it's really frightening but if you try to look at it as something that will save your life throughout your treatment, it somehow makes things a bit easier.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 05:51PM desdemona222b wrote: Irish - I've had the same symptoms - I have a strong history of respiratory problems since I was a baby - lots of asthma, pneumonia, that sort of stuff.  I had radiation therapy to the left breast and lung about 8 years ago and that was my "bad lung" to begin with.  I know you're doctored out right now, but I'd strongly advise you to see a good pulmonologist.  I finally did that a couple of years ago after being way over medicated by my primary care physician - he had me on a nebulizer and two other inhalers as well as prednisone and I still couldn't breath.  When I finally went to the pulmonoligist, he set me straight.  Plus, they can do a diagnostic on you that will eliminate any guess work about what the problem is related to.

Remember, most biopsies come out benign.  Let us know what the path report says.

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2009 02:44PM desdemona222b wrote: sarabhealed - I don't know where you're getting your information but this article indicates that you statement about overall survival is not correct.  http://health.dailynewscentral.com/content/view/2019/63 Radiologists spend hours and hours working you up so that they don't do any harm to your heart and very little to your lungs.  The beam is set so that it hits the breast and underlying tissue but doesn't penetrate far enough to injure the heart. mom - I live in Atlanta, too.  There are a lot of outstanding cancer centers here where you could get a second opinion if you like.  I don't know where you live, but I bet you could get a recommendation for a good radiologist.   I'd do what your medical team recommends.

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2009 05:04AM desdemona222b wrote: They will give you lidocaine gel to help with soreness and redness if you request it.  It works wonders. I don't remember having much flaking during the treatments at all - only afterward when the skin began to heal. I believe that one reason they don't want you using lotion or creams is because, as you near the finish line, your skin gets more and more fragile.  The underlying tissue also gets really fragile.  It would be really easy to cause a break in the skin if you're using lotions or creams. I remember they put a little bit of surgical tape (the paper type they use on rads patients) on my breast toward the end.  When I finished my rads, I pulled it off and the skin pull off with it - yowee.  I can see where rubbing the breast with lotion would risk something similar happening.
Posts.Title: no creams and lotion allowed during Radiations See Roya

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2009 07:50AM desdemona222b wrote: This is the kind of thing I wore throughout my radiation therapy.  If you order the bra in a large size, it will come down even lower on the body.  I was actually lucky enough to find a spandex undershirt for working out in and that was perfect.  You can get stuff like this in XXL at places like Target. The key is not having anything binding you underneath your breasts because that area get REALLY fragile and sore.  Also, you need to powder the undersides of your breasts so the skin isn't rubbing against damp skin.  http://www.hanes.com/Hanes/Products/Women-Hanes/Women_ShopByCategory-Hanes/Women_Bras-Hanes/Women_Bras_WireFreeBras-Hanes/G467.aspx

Posts.Title: I got my results today nikkiea76 lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2009 04:15AM - edited Jun 3, 2009 04:21AM by desdemona222b Why don't you ladies believe your radiation oncs about creams holding in the heat?  They've certainly had an awful lot of experience in what they're doing.  Another reason is rubbing stuff all over the irradiated breast every day can cause the skin to break down as it gets very fragile. When I got a skin reaction, my rads onc gave me a tube of Lidocaine gel - it worked wonders for the pain.  Since it isn't a cream, it doesn't hold in the heat. You need to be especially careful if you have sensitive skin.  They also tell you not to scrub or wash your breast for the same reason.  It will get pretty gross looking prior to the end of treatment, but if you try to wash away the debris it's going to tear the skin up.  Rads sorta cook the flesh through and through, so the skin may look okay on the outside and still be extremely broken down underneath.

Posts.Title: back to the normal apple apple cmhartley

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2009 02:54PM desdemona222b wrote: I'm really sorry to hear you're having to deal with insensitive doctors on top of dealing with your diagnosis. My doctors were wonderful and patient - I don't know how I could have handled difficult docs on top of the diagnosis.  I had DCIS 6 years ago, and my doctors (all three - the oncological surgeon, the radiologist, and the oncologist) told me that lumpectomy with radiation was the safest option in my case even though survival stats are about the same.   I was told the radiation would penetrate to areas below the mammogram level where more DCIS could be lurking undiscovered. I've seen women on this board who say their doctors recommended mastectomy over lumpectomy with radiation, but that was definitely not the case with me.  I was given the option of have a mastectomy, however.  It's really an individual choice and I'm not sure why they're not giving you that option.  An awful lot has been said in the past decade about women getting unnecessary mastectomies - a lot of criticism has been leveled at the medical community and I guess there is a movement to spare the breast at all costs in some communities. You certainly have the right to choose the course you want and feel safest with - I hope you can find a more sensitive medical team.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with ILC & need doctor references cat08 Firni

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2013 10:32AM desdemona222b wrote: I had a lumpectomy in January, 2002 and I still have pain on occasion, sometimes very sharp.  I also have muscle spasms in that area regularly, and I have a keloid scar from the rads on the underside of the breast that just keeps getting bigger and more painful.  Having said all that, I have learned to deal with the pain and I am grateful to be alive and in only moderate pain on occasion.
Posts.Title: Pain in lumpectomy site years later Rachel1 mom2bunky

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 11:57AM desdemona222b wrote: I have it, but it can be caused by a lot of things.  You can get it just from having repeated bouts of bronchitis or pneumonia, from being asthmatic, or even from acid reflux disease.  My lungs have been scarred since I was a child from asthma and infections, but I recently had to go to a pulmonologist because my asthma got so bad during the summer.  He blamed the scarring on acid reflux, not the radiation therapy. They only radiate a very thin layer of the lung from I was told, so any scarring shouldn't extend into the alveoli, etc.  But I don't know if they're that conservative in all cases.  Anyway, it sounds like you may have an infection. I would just wait and see if you get any better and then go to the pulmonologist if I were you.  I'm living on 74% lung function right now and it really isn't that bad at all - my life is perfectly normal.
Posts.Title: AFTER radiation: lung fibrosis??? Myrajuc Imasurvivor

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2009 02:10PM desdemona222b wrote: conniewu - I was diagnosed 7 years ago with LCIS when I had my lumpectomy for DCIS, and I had ADH as well.  They don't treat either one.  The risk of developing breast cancer from LCIS is very small. Here's an article on the subject:  http://www.cancerbackup.org.uk/Cancertype/Breast/DCISLCIS/LCIS Hope this helps.  It sounds like you're just fine, but I understand what it's like to go through a cancer scare.  Very traumatic.

Posts.Title: Sports bras cutting into sential node scars samiam40 lazydaisy

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2011 08:44PM - edited Jun 22, 2011 08:47PM by desdemona222b Hi, worried - There are many different types of breast cancer, some much more treatable than others, and as barbe said, they can't get the true size of it until the pathology report comes in from the surgery. They usually only get the type of cancer with the biopsy report, then after surgery, they get the "whole story" from the entire tumor area and lymph node biopsy. Basically, they can see certain things on mammograms and ultrasound that are usually a dead giveaway that it's cancer, such as spicules (NOT saying this is the case w/ your mother, though - the path report is the final word.)  The best thing you can do right now is try to help your mom just take this one day at a time, easy does it.  The diagnostic process is slow and very traumatic - you'll both feel better after you actually know what is going on and get a treatment plan.  Until you have all the information you need, just hope for the best and try to stay strong!  Just remember, there are many very effective treatments for breast cancer these days and you and your mom should try to remain optimistic, hard as it is.

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2009 09:24PM desdemona222b wrote: The radiation therapy isn't that bad at all.  The fear is much worse.  I went through 7 weeks of it and worked the whole time with the exception of the last week.  Best of luck to your sister.  Being diagnosed with ILC is way better than being diagnosed with melanoma, btw.

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2009 06:41PM desdemona222b wrote: Hi, Bonita - I guess all the ladies on this forum have been through what you describe, so you're in good company here.  When I was first diagnosed, I was told that the type I have is curable but I didn't believe them.  I was sooooooo frightened!  But honestly, it has been six years now and my life is completely back to normal. Try to take it one day at a time and  don't hesitate to ask your doc for sedatives if necessary - Xanax can help a lot during the diagnostic process.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2009 03:13PM desdemona222b wrote: OUCH!  The same thing happened to me in one place.  So needless, too. I wouldn't let them put tape on me the whole time until the very end when one of them slipped a piece on without telling me.  Mine healed in a reasonable length of time, don't remember how long it took.  I used lidocained gel on it.  Hope you get to feeling better. BTW, there is some sort of substance they're supposed to use to get the tape off instead of just ripping it off along with your skin.  If they didn't do that, you should complain about it.

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 01:52PM desdemona222b wrote: Hi, Jeannette - Most of the time the radiologist will comment briefly on his findings when you have a diagnostic mammogram because they are referring you for a biopsy, so it's normal for them to tell you why you need a biopsy.  All of us have been there and experienced the terror, so we completely sympathize.  The diagnostic process is pretty long and drawn out - it's probably the worst part because of the fear.  The actual treatment I had wasn't near as bad as the fear. (((Hugs)))

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2009 02:10PM desdemona222b wrote: I had 37 radiation treatments with boosters.   Honestly, it wasn't that bad - I worked until the last week.  I would say the last couple of weeks were the toughest.  Your breast will get sore about halfway through the treatment, but all in all it's not that bad if you haven't had chemo first.
Posts.Title: side effects of radiation therapy Maria217 Imasurvivor

Posts.Content: May 1, 2009 10:47AM desdemona222b wrote: Hi, ladies. kat said: Here's something to think about.................had my cancer been in my left breast I was told that some form of heart damage "COULD happen" from rads. Now think about this,  the heart is a muscle.  If it can cause damage to the heart then what makes other muscles in the body any different?  They have to be really careful when radiating the left side to avoid the xrays from hitting your heart.  The xrays will damage anything they come into contact with.  The other muscles in your body aren't irradiated with the exception of the pectoral muscle and other muscles under the armpit, etc.  I have really bad muscle spasms in my pec muscle that don't seem like they will ever go away. Your body is awfully taxed by surgery, rads, and chemo because it's working so hard to build new, healthy cells, etc.  I'm sure the strain can cause many unpleasant symptoms like joint pain, etc.  I didn't have any but I hope you gals get to feeling better soon.
Posts.Title: Muscle/joint pain after radiation? kat06365 Larai

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2011 11:54AM desdemona222b wrote: Hi, Cathi - I confess that I have been lurking and just wanted to let your know I am praying for you and your family, especially the children.  Don't quite understand, though - Amanda is your daughter and had a 7-year-old removed from the home in NY that you didn't know existed?  Am I misunderstanding? Barbe - it isn't that easy to get someone involuntarily committed in the States - you can have them held for 48 hours if they are a danger to themselves or others (drug abuse situtations and true madness, usually), but they let them go and rarely commit even the craziest person.  You literally have to be criminally insane to get committed for any length of time.  I'll give you an example - I was a social worker long ago and had a schizophrenic woman applying for assistance.  She refused to cooperate with the regs about providing verfication of anything at all, instead she just threatened to kill me if I didn't certify her.  My supervisor finally told me to just "do what you have to do."  The agency was very familiar with this woman and she could not be committed because she hadn't harmed anyone yet.

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2011 12:16PM desdemona222b wrote: Oh, I agree completely that she is desperately ill.  The whole thing is extremely sad.  It brings back some terrible memories.  I recall in particular a very small boy, only about 3 years maybe, who would always come knock on our door after dark wanting to know if my little boy could play.  One night, it was about 11:00 PM.  I don't know why I didn't bring him in and call the authorities right then, thinking back on it.  I was very torn up by it.  One day I saw him in the laundry room and he had this huge knot on his cheekbone and I asked him what happened to his face.  He said, "My daddy hit me."  I call CPS immediately only to get a letter about three days later saying the child abuse was "unsubstantiated."  God, that just gave me nightmares.  The law requires an emergency visit to any child who has suffered a blow to the face or head, so how on earth was a big egg with bruising just above his eye "unsubstantiated?"  It's so unbearably horrible.  Cathi, I don't know how you can stand it - I am praying for you and the kids.  I would be a basket case from all this!
Posts.Title: please help sueps barbe1958

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2009 06:23PM desdemona222b wrote: Acid reflux definitely causes difficulty swallowing.  I have it really bad - if you suffer from a lot of heartburn you should see your doctor as heartburn can cause esophogeal cancer.
Posts.Title: Difficulty swallowing, a radiation side efffect? nanabolini yoga_girl

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2008 03:49PM desdemona222b wrote: Hi, sueps - Try your level best not to let your imagination run away with you - it's not likely that every ache and pain is related to cancer.  It will take awhile for the shock to subside - in the meantime, put on the bravest face you can and carry on. The very worst thing a person can do in such a situation, IMO, is stay home from work.  It's really hard to keep going in when things are so scary - it seems like resting and regrouping will help.  But to me, actually giving in to the temptation to just collapse is a bad one - in my experience, all you have to do is think about what's going on and obsess about it, whereas if you're at work you can at least partially get out of that mindset. It's perfectly normal to swear and curse the lump while driving, showering, or cleaning house.    BTW - there's really no way they can get ALL the lymph nodes - there's millions of them.  The usual amount is 9-12.
